Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story:
My phone buzzed on the bench beside me, the vibration echoing in the quiet of the synagogue. I glanced at the screen—three new emails, all marked urgent. The leadership team needed my confirmation for tomorrow’s meeting with our external partner, and I knew they expected a prompt reply. I could almost hear my manager’s voice: “We need to lock this down today.” 

But tonight, I wasn’t just a colleague. I was here as a member of my community, about to chant my assigned Torah portion. The rabbi had reminded me how important it was to be present, to honor my commitment to the congregation. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in on me—the responsibility to my team, the promise to my faith. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, torn between the urgent demands of work and the sacred stillness of the sanctuary.
